newsitem.title: UK: WORLD BONDS -US market daunted by 6.50 pct yield.
newsitem.headline: WORLD BONDS -US market daunted by 6.50 pct yield.

text.p: The threat of inflation may not be visible now but U.S. bonds will be hard-pushed to extend a staggering rally beyond the 6.50 percent yield barrier, economists said on Thursday.
The 30-year bond, yielding 6.56 percent against more than 7.0 in April, is faced with the daunting challenge of piercing 6.50 and heading for levels not seen since November 1996.
Few economists think it will.

"It's the kind of level that many investors set as the target so we're going to see more and more profit taking the closer we get to that," said Stephen Lewis, chief economist at London Bond Broking Company.
"In the absence of some special piece of news, which doesn't want to be on the horizon at the moment, I think we're going to stall around here," he added.
Against this background, analysts also say European debt may finally regain some ground against the U.S., which has outperformed Bunds in recent months.
Soft data have fuelled a meteoric rally, with September futures surfacing above 114-00 this week, up nearly six full points since late May. By 1230 GMT, they stood 7/32 lower on the day at 113-22.
Economists think the honeymoon over the U.S. economy will soon end and demand-led forces could pose problems.
Treasuries look overpriced, particularly at the short end, they say, and the market is counting on interest rate scenarios that are too optimistic.

"I'm marginally friendly but I would preface that with the very significant caveat that the market is rather expensive at these levels," said Michael Derks, fixed income strategist at Deutsche Morgan Grenfell.
The Federal Reserve, so far in no hurry to pull the trigger on rates, may not be able to resist taking pre-emptive action in the autumn.

"The market which is focusing almost exclusively on the wage component of costs may be overlooking what's going on on the margin side. We may be seeing a bit of demand-pull inflation rather than cost-pull," said Lewis.
Investors' focus will next week sharpen on June consumer prices and industrial production.

According to Adam Chester, international bond strategist at Yamaichi International Europe, the long bond yield can retrace back to 6.75 percent on a strong set of figures. Any mild data, although unlikely, would help it slide through 6.50 to hit 6.35 percent.
"We are sceptical. The data could surprise on the downside and the market could be in for a bit of a correction," Chester said, adding the short end would be hit hardest.
Economists will also seek clues from Fed chairman Alan Greenspan's Humphrey-Hawkins testimony on July 22.

A report in BusinessWeek this week quoted Greenspan as saying the U.S. economy was going through a dramatic change in productivity. But that optimism might not be repeated in Humphrey-Hawkins, analysts said.
"My view is that he will be as non-committal as ever and that may disappoint the market in its current frame of mind," said Lewis of London Bond Broking.
Economists expect the U.S. yield curve to steepen in the medium term as long bond yields rise, although further flattening can be expected near-term.
The U.S. was also likely to underperform Europe where a euphoria over economic and monetary union (EMU) is feeding a blistering rally in most bonds.

Economists said German Bunds could draw some comfort from the government's budget plans which will be unveiled on Friday. Chester said the T-note/Bund spread could pull out to 90 basis over the coming weeks from around 78 now.
-- International Bonds Unit +44-171-542 8663
